review_full_content_1: I used to buy one of these rolls every few months to cut up for treats to use when training. Dogs loved them, they were easy to handle and stored well in the freezer. Small pieces could be tossed to the dog when teaching a stay.The formulation has changed. This is a finer grind, wetter and stickier. It does not slice well and turns to powder when dried out a little. I could mold little balls by rolling some between my fingertips, but that's not something I want to do with the entire roll. The dogs still love the taste so this is probably good as an additive to a meal, or to hide pills in, but no longer meets my needs at all.

I wish it were labeled "turkey and turkey liver" because the two affect the digestive system very differently.

review_full_content_0: I feed my toy poodle puppy one heaping tablespoon wet mixed into about 1/4 cup dry lamb limited ingredient kibble.  She has this and water available to eat when she wants and usually finishes the bowl by the end of the day.  She is jumping around early in the morning to come out to the kitchen to eat!  I get the smaller cans and purchased a food saver lid to keep can in frig until gone after opening.  She usually goes through a can in less than a week.  Food is pricy, but she likes it, and lamb agrees with most dogs.  I feel like ingredients are good for her, also.  She is growing and quite active.
review_full_content_1:
I have one of those dogs who will eat ANYTHING. He's never refused a food. We've always said that if this dog ever turns away a food it has to be reallllly bad stuff.

As he's gotten older, his digestive tract has become more sensitive, so my vet recommended putting him on an LID diet. Since we've fed Nature's Variety products to our cat for a while now and she's doing great on Instinct brand, we decided to go with this line.

First, he walked away from the dry food plain, or soaked. So we tried mixing the canned (in this case, the lamb flavor) version of Instinct LID into the food.

I'm sitting here looking at yet another bowl of food, with little pieces of kibble taken out and scattered around the floor beside it, but not a bite of it actually eaten. $30-and-change for the bag of dry food, $30-and-change for the case of cans, and looks like I'll be donating them to our local rescue center.

A huge "thumbs down" from the dog who will eat anything.

However, I did check that I would recommend the brand to a friend, because I still believe that Nature's Variety makes a good, healthy, holistic product. I guess it just tastes like sawdust.

(Sidenote: he'll still eat pretty much anything else put in front of him, by the way, so it's not his appetite over-all that is the problem.)

After losing her at 16, I adopted a young puppy and she also has a sensitive stomach. Luckily, I had some of the cans (with the Beagle) on them left and tried this food with her. Yep. No more runny stools and she loves this. So other than the confusing label issue I would highly recommend this food as it has worked for both of my female dogs puppy to senior.  So thanks to you Dave for a great product, and I also want to thank Chewy's customer service people for being so helpful. Your kindness is greatly appreciated.

review_full_content_0: My veterinarian wanted me to feed my Golden Retriever Innova Evo grain free beef dog food in connection with dealing with a major health issue.  My Golden Retriever loves the flavor of this wet dog food and gobbles it down.  However, the wet dog food by itself is rather mushy and what you might call a meat slop.  I do not feed the Evo 95 to the dog by itself, but use it as an additive to moistened solid dry dog food, about a 50/50 mix, and this ends up with a consistency with some body.  This ends up with what I would consider a reasonably firm normal stool.  The solid dog food I use is the Blue Buffalo grain free beef mix because for some reason my Golden will not eat the Evo dry grain free beef dog food.  My Golden is doing very well on the combination of the Evo 95 moist dog food mixed with Blue Buffalo grain free dry mix. I highly recommend the EVO 95 moist dog food, but be advised it is like a beef mush.

review_full_content_0: Been feeding my 10 year old shepherd/heeler mix Eukanuba dry food for a few years. She has developed an allergy to chicken so had to change her food. Vet recommended dog food made with rabbit or kangaroo!! Found out it's super expensive. Decided to try Nature's Recipe with salmon, sweet potato and pumpkin. Found it on sale at Chewy. Had a new bag of Eukanuba and asked if it could be returned for a refund. Chewy rep gave me a full refund and told me to donate the bag to a local charity. What a great way to handle the request. Find prices great at Chewy and the reps very pleasant and helpful. Will continue to buy from them for both of my dogs. P.S. my 11 year old puppy mill rescue gets the canned food because she has no teeth. Chewy's price is well below the chain dog food stores.
review_full_content_1: My Border Collie eats it, but then he isn't a fussy eater. The ingredients are all finely ground into a sticky paste that requires a second spoon or a finger to get it off the first spoon. Then it sticks to the second spoon or finger.  It just seems to stick to everything. Since the ingredients are finely ground and blended together, you can't really tell what it contains. The label says two of the primary ingredients are Chicken By-Products and Beef-Products which are a clever name for undesirable parts.  Also, a lot of the ingredients are chemical names that are difficult to spell and pronounce, for example...Fructooligosaccharides!  What is that?  On the positive side, besides my dog eating it, the stickiness of the product helps to conceal his medication that comes in pill form. review_full_content_0:
Disclaimer: I am a "people-food for doggies" cynic. My dog only eats "people food" when it fell off my plate and hit the floor. Making doggie food look like stew-for-people misses the point. My dog actually likes dog food that I would never want to eat.

I used to mix Iams lamb pate formula with Iams dry food. My dog would devour it every time. The Iams formula changed (darker red, drier, and with rice-like bits in it) and my dog stopped eating it. I then tried Fromm...that went over very well, but Chewy.com discontinued it. So, at a sales rep's request I tried Earthborn Holistic, which I was told would be a good substitute for the Fromm pate. To my surprise, the EBH looked like a can of Campbell's chunky stew. This is nothing like pate at all. I gave some to my dog...he sniffed it and walked away. Mind you, my dog tries to drink dirt water from the planter pots after it rains and used to eat cat poo. A screen shot of the food uncovered, or a spoonful, would be very helpful. I'll donate the failed product to a shelter (maybe other dogs like stew) and look for a more pulverized meat-based product for my dog.

review_full_content_0:
I almost exclusively buy Blue Wilderness dry food served mixed with canned for my two dogs. I admittedly test out one can purchased at retail and then order in bulk from Chewy if my dogs like it.

Dogs have never had a problem with any other BW product until this one. As a few other reviewers have noted, my dogs had tummy/digestive issues with this product. Multiple rounds of diarrhea plus vomiting several hours after ingesting. My dogs are typically not picky eaters or have digestive issues. They are healthy junior adults. My dog that consumed the most had the worst reaction. To be fair, not sure if quantity consumed could be a contributing factor or how the retail store may have stored the can, etc. 

Therefore, since others have not had these issues, my less than stellar product recommendation comes with a caution given my personal experience. To be clear, I am a very happy Chewy.com customer and BW product consumer for all my Chewy purchases to date and am confident I will continue to be, but I will not order or try feeding this specific BW product to my dogs again.

review_full_content_1:
For the last couple months I have used Evanger's Organics Cooked Chicken (can, grain-free, gluten-free). I was REALLY impressed and pleased with the product! It REALLY looked like "real cooked chicken"; it was almost white, and you could see the bits of bone/grizzel that had been ground up. Smelled like chicken too. The consistency was great for me to hide my dogs meds in a meatball - not too mushy. They loved it (2 Corgi girls 12 yrs old)! When I got my most recent order, I opened the 1st can and was "shocked" to see it looked like cheap mushy dog food, and it was "red" looking like beef or ? I opened another can..same thing! So disappointed!! I don't "know" what has happened? Is it the wrong recipe in the can, or have they "changed the recipe"? Has there been some kind of mistake at the plant, or something in the can that is not suppose to be there?! I cannot feed this to my dogs without knowing what has happened! As of this writing I am "waiting on a call from the Evanger's Quality Control person". When I get an explanation I will add to this review. This is "why" I only gave 1 star. This is a real "bummer"! Now, I'm out of this food, and don't know if I can get it at the pet store in my area! I feed this as a supplement in dry food, and also for their meds. I was so happy with this product, and I had been using another organic trusted brand for past few yrs, but, I felt Evanger's was a little better price and had a bit larger can, so it lasted a few days longer, etc..I also "noticed" that the "cans" themselves, for my last order & one before, are pretty "dirty", with spots of some kind of liquid that is stained 
"white" on top and some of the bottom of the cans had other crud on them. Had to wash cans off top before opening, as I hoped it was not some kind of pestiside for bugs or something that they spray in the warehouse, or ? Anyway, again, SO DISSAPPOINTED, as I felt the quality was so good, etc...Hope I find out "what has happened"? Has anyone else heard/seen anything about this happening (I do see another person's review talking about this, but don't see if they made an inquiry to Evanger's)?

review_full_content_0: Yoda likes the Hill's Prescription diet canned food.  For some reason she didn't take to the Hill's Prescription kibble; think it was the size which was about double the Buffalo Blue she was so used to having.  Two other dogs on the kibble also like the canned.  Read the ingredients on the can and noticed the hyalouronic acid was not included, as it is in the kibble.  Did I miss something?  Anyway: got a supplement of hyalouronic acid at the health food store and give Yoda those capsules with her meal.  My veterinarian thinks the hyalouronic acid is "The Bomb" that makes the biggest difference for joint mobility; and, I agree.  The canned food is meaty and thick: I scoop out a big round dollop and slice it like meat loaf; then, dice it into smaller bits and mix it in with Buffalo Blue for Senior Dogs: a dash of low-salt organic chicken broth and we're good to go.  ALL of our doggies love it.  I garnish their kibble with a bit of the canned prescription, too; then no one feels left out.  Yum!  Tempted to try it myself!
review_full_content_1:
Dog will be 17 this August and he's showing severe signs of joint disease now... Got this to see if he would eat it (historically, my pets have all shunned Hill's, and I personally have always felt there were better products out there). HE ATE IT!

So, a quickie review:
1 - this is a COMPLETE and BALANCED formula. Some of the SD foods are marked to be fed intermittently or else supplementally, but this one is safe to feed for maintenance and without interruption. I would not give it to a puppy, as the Dry Matter Basis protein is only 20% (adult dogs require at least 18, puppies need more!).

2 - this is the CLOSEST level of DMB Protein I have found! My dog is also showing EARLY signs of kidney disease and I thought that it was a bad idea to reduce his protein intake... Until I researched it and learned that about the minimum for adults (18% based on a dry matter basis), and then checked the foods I had been using in rotation. YIKES, I was killing my dog! I do not feed this alone (I combine it with other lower protein options, ranging from this 20% to 25%), because my dogs have always had all kinds of food and they don't typically accept a "bland, one food forever diet." 

3 - It mashed pretty easy into some of the kibble that we are NOT buying again... I put about 1/4 the can in to see if he'd eat it and it mashed in really nicely actually: not so wet it stuck to everything and also not so dry it crumbled off the food. It has a pretty good texture compared to what I recall of the old SD foods (which were like... gel...). 

4 - NOT a fan of the first 6 ingredients: Corn is the 6th and corn is usually 1, GMO (genetically modified to be either a pesticide or herbicide resistant by producing its own toxins), and 2, not as easy to digest or available for nutrient absorption. And what by product of pork are we talking, exactly, here, Hill's? Organ meats are considered a by product, and I have fed raw organ meats before in my rotation, so that wouldn't bother me. I'm hoping that's what it is (and not something higher in protein but WORTHLESS to digest, such as feet/hoof material...).

I paid 2.79 per can at the veterinarian's office, and Chewy has it .04 cheaper. I'll be buying from Chewy since I'm mixing about 1 can a day into the rest of his food. Not my favorite product but I definitely have to admit that it at least doesn't turn my dog 100% off and make me feel awful for trying to add more "joint stuff" in when and where possible.

6 - the only OTHER complaint I have about this food is the same as the ones coming out of California right now: there is nothing in this formula indicating that it REQUIRES a prescription to purchase. You can buy higher amounts of glucosamine and the rest of the "joint compounds" in concentrated doses pretty much anywhere without an Rx. It annoys me that I have to get an Rx for it, and I'm not sure who exactly enforces this but it's a bit silly, considering I bought it at work today (ok, I work for a vet...) WITHOUT an Rx. My boss didn't think I needed one, but ok, I'll get it... 

Bottom line: Great food to add into your dog's diet, provided you account for calories and ingredients/nutrients and adjust the rest of the diet accordingly. BEST DMB protein level I've found to date, for those seeking safe foods for kidney dogs too!

review_full_content_0:
My furry friend, a 12Y old Malti-tzu, has suffered with IBD for several years now and digestive issues have become more frequent lately. The Great Vets that are treating him wanted to see if an illumination diet would help with his issues. I made the transition (At their request) with the Hill's Prescription Diet  from (11 Years) of Homemade Food consisting of Chicken, Brown Rice, Carrots and Green Beans supplemented with Omega3 Fish Oil. This transition for the first week was done adding the Hill's gradually to his old food formula until it became 100% of his diet.
He still has some issues but he is taking some meds (antibiotics,etc.) His stool at this point is much better and I have to give credit to the Hill's diet.
Chewy also deserves a Big Thank You, especially "Customer Service" for their support and patience with me during my trek to make things better for my Furry friend.
review_full_content_1: The vet prescribed this food for my Jack Russell Terrier for his problem with prolonged loose stool.  I was skeptical that he would eat it only because he always has been a very picky eater, and we had no luck with him eating other prescription food.  Much to my surprise, he ate it.  For the first few weeks, we got by on the supply given us by the Vet.  When that ran out, I ordered a case of this from Chewy.  As soon as I opened the first can, it looked different than the cans the Vet gave me. The food was mushy, and even looked somewhat different than the what the Vet supplied.  And sure enough, my dog refuses it.  Now, I am not only stuck with a case of the food, I am having to start all over with the dogs problems.  Very disappointed at the inconsistent texture and taste between the original cans I had, and what i received.  Very disappointed in the manufacturer.  Cannot recommend

However, I cannot get past the consistency of this food.  It is more like a "paste" than anything else.  It is disgusting because it sticks to the spoon, sticks to my fingers and is just pasty.  I have had a few cases, in the past, where the consistency of the food was not so gooey, but that is not the norm with this food.  I really don't understand this.  I give it to my dogs and yes, they eat it, but I would think it would get stuck in their throat from the gooeyness. I feel bad my dogs have to eat this. review_full_content_0: I have been vegan for 11 months and had no plans to transition my dogs. They all have varying food sensitivities. I bought a case of this just to prove to myself it wouldn't be an option for them. The first day I fed them a few fingers full of it and they went nuts! They ended up eating the whole can as a snack. I thought they'd all have diarrhea or be sick from the sudden change. They all digested it perfectly! Within 3 weeks of being on this, my Italian Greyhound, who was very thin and losing her hair, began growing her hair back and gaining weight! My chihuahua with ulcerative colitis handled it perfectly too. I am simply amazed. It is a little stickier and thicker than the Natural Balance venison & sweet potato they were eating before, so I add a little water to thin it out a bit. Without the water, it seems to stick to the roof of one dog's mouth, but my other 4 don't have this problem.
review_full_content_1: The dogs love this food. All three of them eat every bite, but the consistency of the food itself is a paws down for me. It's very thick and gummy, not like a meat based pate at all. It's very hard to incorporate into the dry food especially if you have arthritic hands. Seems like it has a very low moisture content. There's nothing wrong with the food itself, it's an excellent product. Low fat and good for the dogs which makes me happy. Just wish it was easier to serve.

review_full_content_0:
Of all of our pets, Scooby is the pickiest. She loves treats and to steal table food so her dry food habits are terrible. Luckily, she is not as picky when it comes to treats. I have bought a few kinds of canned wet dog food in the past that she turned her nose up to, though, so I am always nervous as to what the results are going to be with her when it comes to even treats. Well, thankfully, this brand was an absolute hit with her! 
 
I love the easy pop tops to I can get it opened quickly. Once opened, the food appeared almost like human food - chunky and in nice gravy sauce. I love this style much better than the pate, as does Scooby. For me, pate is a pain in the tushy to get out the can and requires utensils to scoop it out. This particular style just pours right out into her bowl with no issues. As soon as I got it in the bowl Scooby could barely sit and wait. She was whimpering and shaking her butt from her tail wagging so hard. she then gobbled it down as if she hadn't eaten in months! By the time she was done I swear that bowl looked cleaner than when I wash it in the dishwasher! Needless to say, this was a HUGE hit with Scooby as well as me as the pet parent. It was easy to get out, no nasty odor, and the fact it is grain free is quite the bonus. We definitely can recommend this one - even to picky eaters!

review_full_content_0:
My name is  Bosco, a dog of questionable parentage, and I  can be a bit of a pill when it comes to eating!! I have become more so now. You see, on September 18th,  I lost my third GSD Sister. It was a horrible week. Mommy and Daddy were so upset. They were running to the vets from Monday Sept 11 thru Sept 13. I was very worried. Mommy kept saying it did not look good for Riley. I don't understand this: Mommy and Daddy in April, 2013 took Sasha to the  vets. Sasha never came back home to me Margo and Riley. Mom would try to talk to me about Sasha, but could only cry!! (She still cannot talk about Sasha without crying.) Then in August, 2016, they took Margo to the vet. She didn't come home!!i 
So Daddy feeds me in the morning and Mom feeds me at night. I like when Dad feeds me. He is not stingy with the Taste of Wild canned!! Mom keeps my on a diet!! They mix a couple of tablespoons of TOW mixing it in with my dry (Taste of Wild). It is SOO good. I think I like the TOW canned,  better than table-scraps!! AND I do know that the dog food is much better for me. 
When I eat TOW dry with the canned TOW, I look DARN good!! My coat gets so shiny, and soft, almost silky!!!

Now I am going tell a secret, DON'T, PLEASE, do not tell my Mommy or Daddy!! I sometimes act like I am not being a good eater. See, i know they will get worried about my not eating !! When they get worried...... You guessed it, I get canned doggie food. I learned that trick from my GSD Sister Sasha!! LOL!! Any ways I guess the bottom-line is I DO LIKE THE TASTE of WILD!!! 
I would recommend you give your furbabies, small pups, like Yorkies or the larger breeds, GSDs, or St. Bernards!! 
AND ANY of my fellow fur-brothers and fur-sisters who read this, try being fussy and do not gobble down that bowl of food to see if your parents feel badly and provide a treat by adding some canned Taste of Wild. [Actually, if you want my opinion, you should hold out for a total diet of ToW!! ]

[This is dedicated to my GSDs Sisters!! I know I wasn't always the best little brother, but I sure do miss you all. Riley, I know it is difficult to believe, that I miss you terribly. Every once in a while,I think I hear you. I go looking through the house looking for you...and Daddy, has been a real mess. Riley you weren't supposed to leave so soon... Why did you go?? ]

Chewy sent 2 replacement cases and 23 out of those 24 had mold on them. So out of 48 cans 44 had mold. I feed this to my senior dog with digestion issues and no teeth, I also feed a spoonful to my foster dog who is nursing puppies. I couldn't feed them any of this. Needless to say I am abandoning this brand in search of something better.
You get what you pay for. 
Thankfully Chewy refunded my purchase.

review_full_content_0:
I have a cattle dog/husky mix, 8 months old.  I guess she has listened to the cats on now to be picky about food.  :/
Seems like she gets tired of foods quickly and turns her nose up.  This food is pretty simple.  It has shreds of chicken or beef, depending on flavor, some veggies and bits of pumpkin or sweet potato.  It has enough liquid so that when mixed with dry kibble it gets gobbled up.  I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because it's pretty pricey for simple ingredients.  I wish it wasn't made in Thailand.  I have read all about how the facilities there are inspected and that they are supposed to be higher graded than a lot of the ones in the USA. Even so, I would prefer to have all ingredients from the USA if possible but if my dog continues to like it and the ingredient list is simple,without a lot of other ingredients, then I can't argue with that.  Maybe it's pricey because it is made in Thailand ?  My dog seems to prefer the chicken flavor over the beef.

review_full_content_0: Oliver gets wet food every other evening for dinner. The other meals are dry food. He has Spaniel ears which soak up any liquid in his food, and this has just the right amount to satisfy him without soaking his ears. If you have any breed with long floppy ears, you know what I mean. He loves the flavor!
review_full_content_1: My almost 11 YO Standard Poodle is not driven by food to begin with though isn't what I would call a picky eater either (food is just not a driving force in her life), very slow eater and is now limited to a non beef, chicken, etc diet, (no grain always)--but is a very athletic active dog so needs to eat a good bit and she only eats limited amount of this. I have been feeding Dave's salmon and Canidae's salmon/fish canned but Canidae is temporarily OS (I hope) so took Chewy up on choosing a different food.  My 3 YO Cavalier King Charles will eat anything (and everything LOL) and is limited to 1/4 cup dry 2x and 1 T canned 2x and likes it, but Molly (SP) licks the gravy off and will very slowly eat some and quits.  I started mixing 1/2 and 1/2 with Dave's to get her to eat more.  I don't think there is a thing wrong with the food, but for any others with dogs that prefer a paté type food, this will not do--quite firm chunks that don't even mash easily.  I will use the 2 cases and not order more. review_full_content_0: This is a review of the Caesar filets food, but I have to mention that recently our English Bulldog (Bella) had not been doing well. At almost 12 years old, she's outlived most of her breed. As is typical with Bulldogs (and short nose breeds), she started to have more trouble lately breathing. She couldn't eat the Blue Buffalo food (even wet) our other dogs and her usually eat. The Caesar filets in sauce helped her eat, and gave her the opportunity to take the medicine to help her feel better. I know this isn't as much a review focused on the food, but this particular food was exactly what she needed and was able to eat. Nothing else was helping (my husband had to hand feed her the last few days), but the filets in sauce was easy for her to eat & digest. Unfortunately, she crossed over the Rainbow Bridge today, and as hard as it is to take, our other 2 dogs who shared some of the new, tasty Caesar filets, were able to eat their usual dry food with some of this wet food in strips mixed in. Thank you to Chewy.com for making it so easy to get whatever we need and easy to change and adjust to our pets' needs. The many options were great in helping us find what Bella could enjoy for awhile & keeping our other fur babies taken care of. Tough day, but this particular food was key to getting our girl as good as she good be.

review_full_content_0: When my Vet found crystals in my morkie's urine he prescribed Science Diet Urinary Care food and gave us a few cans of the regular food to try.  He suggested mixing half of the food with her regular food for a few days to gradually change over.  Snookie did not like the food and stopped eating.  Knowing she liked chicken I decided to check the Chewy app for a chicken flavored prescription food and found this chicken stew and the chicken dry food as well.  I spoke to my Vet and explained the situation and he agreed to let us try the chicken flavor food so we ordered from Chewy and received the package within 2 days.  We gave Snookie a can of the chicken stew that night and she loved it.  She didn't walk away from her dish until she finished the food and proceeded to lick her bowl clean.  Now she gets the dry food in the morning and the stew at night and she loves them both.  In addition, after retesting her urine about a month later there were no crystals detected.  I would highly recommend this food and ordering it from Chewy.  They took care of obtaining the prescription before filling the order and still delivered the food in 2 days.  Chewy has made Snookie, as well as her human, very happy!

It cases were incased in a heavy duty corrugated cardboard box inside the bigger box with the bag of dry food. The cans were perfect, no dings or dents. The bag of dog food was not ripped or damaged. I truly appreciate the effort Chewy has shown on my first order. I will definitely be with you for as long as my pups are with me. Thank you Chewy for this wonderful service,
Daisy and Hank's Mom

review_full_content_0:
This is the best diet to give your pet if they have kidney disease.  
Also very bland so good on sensitive tummies too!  
My dog (Autumn-10 yr old SF brindle boxer)  prefers the original pate version (which I think is gross) but as long as she eats it and likes it I am fine with that.  =-).  They also make 2 "stew style" recipes that most dogs (just not mine-because it has miniscule pieces of carrot in it) really like.  
Hills has really stepped up with their renal control diets.  In the olden days is was so gross most pets (especially cats) wouldn't eat it.
The diet is only good if the animal actually ingests it.  So kudos to Hills for their work on this product to make it MUCH more palatable for the animals.  Hope this keeps Autumn going for a long time.  =-)

He did eat some with mostly treats on it in order to start the feeding process.  Now even if we put treats on it he won't touch it, and it's been like this for a week.  He's eating rice, potatoes, and chicken.  Very unhappy with the changes to the formula!  Had to give it one star in order to rate, but I wouldn't have other wise given it any stars.

review_full_content_0: My Rottie pup has been on the Royal Canin Hydrolyzed Protein diet for almost 3 months due to severe protein allergies. One day he just looked at me and said "Nope, not eating this anymore". I tried everything short of standing on my head to get him to eat. Called the vet, she said we could now try one of the selected protein formulas. He went nuts when I brought it home and filled his bowl!! The hydrolyzed protein formula saved his life and stabilized his digestive system which allowed time for it to heal, but I think the flavor was lacking. Now that he is on an actual meat formula he is so happy! Another prescription was needed for this food also, but Chewy got on the phone with my vet right away and shipped it out the next day! So far my pup has been eating this formula for a week and we haven't seen any adverse reactions. Once again, thank you Royal Canin for making quality foods for our special needs pets and thank you Chewy for working so fast to get my pup his much needed prescription food!
review_full_content_1: we're testing my little guy for food allergies, which has severely limited food options. One container is exactly enough for her to eat it all without getting too full or wasting any. I have not thrown a single bit of this away, where it seemed the other things I was throwing away all but a bite or two that I put down. She licks the bowl clean but does not ask for more. review_full_content_0:
My name is Guy, short for McGuyver. Most people call me Butters, though. (That's from a funny show called "South Park" that my family watches.) I answer to just about anything, though. I'm a good boy! People tell me that all the time!

Not to long ago I got very sick. I was very scared and thought I was dying! My parents took me to an animal ER. I had pancreatitis, and it hurt something awful! I cried and cried. But the nice ER doctor gave me medicine, and I started feeling better pretty quick.

My parents took me to see my regular vet after the weekend. He told them that I had to be on a special diet. So now I get Hill's Prescription dog food--in a can!!! I used to only get canned food for a treat, but now I get it every meal!

My parents and I absolutely love chewy.com! We get everything that I need -- and sometimes a few extra surprises just for me! Having my food delivered straight to the house really saves my parents a lot of time. It automatically comes every four weeks, so no one has to worry about if I have enough food anymore!!!

Thanks, chewy.com!
Your friend,
McGuyver

I have a little cairn terrier named Eddie.  I love the little guy.  He was vomiting often and had loose stools.  I took Eddie to the Vet and his tests results were for pancreatitis.  The Vet said Eddie should be restricted to a low fat diet and recommended Royal Canin Low Fat dog food.  It has worked.  Eddie is doing very well now, and best of all he loves this food.  I mean really loves it.

This dog food requires a prescription and I was getting it from my Vet, but a few weeks ago they were out and I was stuck.  Ordered it from Chewy.com.  They verified the Rx from the Vet and all is well again.  Fair pricing and very fast shipping.  Will be purchasing future orders of this product from Chewy.com.

This Canine Caviar Goat fits that bill better than anything else I found. I have to give her a bit less than recommended for her weight. I add a nice helping of a mixture of fresh ground organic vegetables to each meal. Also I add the Holistic Blend vitamins and minerals sold here @ Chewy. She loves her food!! I highly recommend this product. Btw, I froze about 1/3 of the 2nd can in a freezer bag. I'm using it now, and it seems fine. Now I won't have to worry about the last of the Can going bad in the fridge.

review_full_content_0:
Having read the other reviews for this product, in particular, and Weruva, in general, I really, REALLY wanted to like this canned dog food. But, the long and the short of it is that only one of my 2 dogs likes it, and I am just not wow-ed by this product.

I really like that Weruva makes their products in facilities with human-grade standards. I really like that Weruva uses only wild-caught tuna and does not accept tuna from unlisted, unregistered fishing boats. And, as the other reviews, and Weruva itself, point out, you can see chunks of tuna meat in the product. It is not a homogenized mush, but similar to a human-grade soup. You see chunks of vegetables as well. It is much lower in fat than most canned dog foods (see nutritional analysis below). I very much like the fact that pumpkin is the chief vegetable ingredient (one of several), which is very nutritious and less problematic than potato for allergic dogs. And, to be fair, one of my two hyper-allergic dogs absolutely loves it!

So, what gives? Why do I not recommend this product and only give it a 3.0? Because you (and I) pay up to $10 more per case than the average premium canned dog food for a product that is less than 10% protein for all that, and the can is labeled "Product of Thailand." Over and above that, although there are indeed chunks of tuna in the product, there are not that many; most of the tuna is still in flakes. This is the first time that I have used a Weruva product. I also notice that I am writing this review a year later than 2 of the other 3 reviews. Perhaps the formulation/recipe for this product has changed in the meantime. I just don't know.

Here is the nutritional analysis: Crude Protein #min#: 8%; Crude Fat #min#: 1.4%; Crude Fiber #max#: 0.5%; moisture #max#: 85%; Ash #max#: 1.5%.

It just seems that a person can spend his/her money more sensibly than on an expensive product of only 8% protein that is a "product of Thailand" and which only one of my dogs loves.
pos_review_content: I know that this product is more expensive than most, but it has certainly been worth it. Mackenzie was very sick and not eating. I thought I'd try Weruva, as I feed it to my 2 cats. She dances when she sees it coming and licks the bowl clean! It is very high quality food.

review_full_content_0:
My dog lost her appetite in the last 2 weeks of her gestation due to size of puppies compressing her stomach. I was at a loss on what would make her keep eating. I took a chance on this and it works. Her mouth literally drooled when I opened up the cans.
Unfortunately this causes food pickiness afterward that is hard to break. The food is so delicious that the dog won't want to go back to all dry food easily. But if your pregnant female is not eating at all, then this is worth the price to keep her interested. Small cans are beneficial for portion size to make meals small and frequent.
Her puppies came out very large and healthy, all thriving. I plan to use this again for weaning puppies.

review_full_content_0: While some dog foods have a more liquid consistency, this one has the worst kind of liquid composition. Frankly, it looks exactly like throw-up, or something a dog would vomit up after eating too much, or the wrong meal. But, what made it worse was the foul smell. Granted, a lot of dog foods are not the best smelling, but this food had a strong and sour stench that wreaked in the kitchen and house, and in Nicky's dish, even after she ate it all. As for liking this food, our Pyrenees, who eats anything and everything--and could eat all day-- did not finish this food after about the third can, because she couldn't bear it either.  I like making a nice mix of wet and dry for her--I tried my best with this food, and  even added a little cheese. Still,  she just started to reject it. It got to the point where she would walk out of the kitchen as I opened the can. I found myself only adding a little of this wet food to the kibble and tossing most down the drain with lots of hot water and soap. I try all brands and I am convinced this is just an "icky" dog food--I wonder what on EARTH is mixed in here. And, yes, it is salmon (and fish can smell quite strong), but I have a feeling the other meats would be just as vile in terms of consistency and stench. I will never try this brand again. There are four cans left in the cupboard, and I don't even want to donate them.   The ONE star rating is because the brand name, CANINE CAVIAR, is really good--it is a shame the product is horrific.

review_full_content_0: Like other reviewers, my 8 year old Chihuahua/mix loved the other brand that stopped making their venison canned food (which I don't understand, but whatever...) My pup has IBD and his Vet prescribed that original brand and he did well on it and he loved it. But he didn't like the other proteins (duck and then white fish) that I had to switch him to when I couldn't get their venison. I found Party Animal Heavenly Venison and saw other positive reviews by people that have dogs with tummy issues. So I took a chance. I am happy to say that my pup really loves this food and he has had no stomach issues for the 2-3 weeks he has been eating it - which is a big deal because his IBD pain & discomfort was hitting him about once a week leading up to this switch.  His poop is excellent and he is maintaining his weight. So far so good & my fingers are crossed! I sometimes add some dried venison kibble or maybe a cracker because this brand is not as dense/dry as the other brand, but he still likes it plain. I hope this helps other folks who struggle with their dog's stomach problems.

review_full_content_0:
It's just chicken (parts, meat) and liver (label doesn't specify from what species). It contains no added vitamins, minerals, or carrageenan (horrible ingredient that causes inflammation which leads to a number of health ailments). 

I needed this food for my renal failure cat as it doesn't contain ingredients that require organs to do the extra work of transforming ingredients into usable things. 

The reason I gave this three stars is that it isn't anything special for what the price is. If it were organic, non GMO, and contained specifically named ingredients then I would see the price being justified. This is an average/less than average canned food. It's mixed up mystery chicken and mystery liver and contains nothing extra. If anything this food should cost less than other brands because it lacks every reason for increasing cost.

My renal failure cat doesn't like this food but that's okay b/c my other kitties like it okay. Of course, my dogs would gobble it up if no kitties liked it.

I don't recommend this food unless you need a food that is just meat and water. I will not buy again unless the price is drastically reduced.

Large breed puppies should stay way until Evanger's provides clarification.

review_full_content_0:
All the Nature's Instinct Canned Foods contain this:
Ethylenediamine Dihydriodide
Sometimes listed as EDDI, it appears to be used as an iodine supplement. It may react with sulfates and release free iodine. Calcium Iodate (currently in many pet foods) is indicated as the most stable iodine supplement and would appear to be a better choice of iodine supplements."
(From Dogfood Advisor website)
So one would wonder why Nature's Instinct chose this cheaper version for an iodine supplement. I think I will go back to Ziwi Peak. Its more costly but take a look at their dogfood ingredient list which imo is 75% richer in value for your pet. With NO questionable ingredients!

Evangers canned Duck makes an excellent topper to mix in with the regular Fromm kibble we feed our two dogs. Both the Duck and the Beef flavors our dogs devour their food when this is added. 

It's very fresh, the 6 ounce cans are perfect to split between both dogs meals. The protein level in it seems to be giving our girl more energy. She plays more, she jumps higher, overall we have noticed a difference in her wanting to play more outside now. 

I would highly recommend this brand to anyone with a picky eater, or who is looking for a topper to their regular food. 

Evangers has never had a recall, which is one of the main reasons we chose this brand. 

It comes packaged quite well, yes, you may find a couple of cans dented; though that does not affect the quality of the food.

Interestingly Much of the damage was on the inside of the box as well as the periphery.  This suggests to me that the cans were damaged before packaging.  Extremely difficult to open with an electric and conventional CanOpener and difficult to cap with a rubber can caper Not sure what that tells you about the company.  I brought this up to a Chewy's agent and she offered credit or a refund, I did not ask for it, she brought it up. Two cases were involved : Coco Licious venison & Natural Balance  Buffalo and sweet potato.  I tried sending photos on the site but it was all but impossible. Will be glad to send them on a separate email. I have not received credit or a refund that was promised to me
pos_review_content: I have a Xoloitzcuintle (hairless dog) who has very sensitive skin. He loves this food and I believe it helps keep his hide from getting so dry. I have noticed that I haven't had to moisturize him quite as often.

pos_review_content: I am feeding against the grain products to both my dogs and cats; I have very picky eaters, but all six of my animals run to the food bowl and dive in. This is a great product .
neg_review_content: These cans are unlike any I have bought at local feed store! Doesn't look like chicken looks like beef in both color and texture

pos_review_content: I have two English Bulldogs - the older of my two is a very picky eater. She absolutely LOVES these stews. Not one morsel is left after she finishes eating. Makes me so happy! Love Chewy for their products, prices and service! Amazing!!!!!
neg_review_content: My dog just wont eat it. Wont even look at it. Also, when I open the can there seems to be so much solid fat at the top of the can. I have been removing this fat but its really bad for your dog. I hope everyone else is removing it. Well I wont be buying this again since my dog dont like it.

review_full_content_0: I was looking for a limited ingredient, high quality canned food - both to add to my dogs kibble, and to put his medication in. I purchased the Duck variety. Unfortunately the product is too soupy/runny to hide medication in when first opened up. It does thicken up a bit when placed in the refrigerator, so that helps, but you can basically pour it out of the can like gravy when you first open it. The can does say to shake well before opening so maybe this is the consistency they were going for. My dog likes the flavor okay and I love the limited ingredient list but I'm on the fence about whether or not I'll purchase again.
pos_review_content: I was looking for a limited ingredient, high quality canned food - both to add to my dogs kibble, and to put his medication in. I purchased the Duck variety. Unfortunately the product is too soupy/runny to hide medication in when first opened up. It does thicken up a bit when placed in the refrigerator
neg_review_content: This has been the best food!  However, as I seen someone say above something is going on.  The quality has been horrible!  Very liquid filled and definitely not the same product we used to get!

pos_review_content: I had just adopted a 2 1/2 Old English Bulldog who would only pick at his food. When I added this to his dry dog food, he couldn't wait to eat and leaves nothing in the bowl.
neg_review_content: So watery that I had to "drain" before mixing with my dogs food. Now the duck is also watery. Bought my last case.

review_full_content_0: We've been going crazy trying to figure out what our dog is allergic to. Vet said allergy testing isn't 100% accurate, so recommended going grain free. Did that-dog still was scratching and losing hair. Food with potatoes seemed like it made it even worse. Saw this at a grocery store and decided to try it--especially, since it was only food that was grain and potato free. Since we'd also been feeding grain free chicken/ duck and beef without seeing any improvement, decided to try this one with salmon. Finally, after over a month, she's still scratching some, but her hair is finally growing back. We'd also tried Benadryl (no difference) and now is on 1 Zyrtec daily. Combo of food and meds seems to be working. We also use the same in dry food , so mix the canned with the dry as our 1 year old "puppy" is 80 pounds and eats like a horse!
review_full_content_1: I have been using Nutrisca dog food cans (all varieties) for many years. This last order of the Salmon and Chickpea Stew Recipe was not the same in consistency. It was watered down and like a thick soup. There were less fish "chunks", and the manufacturer said their formula did not change or nor did they have any recalls. They had no explanation for this case and did not seem concerned in the least. Even though I like to give my dog different proteins, I will no longer be feeding this Salmon flavor now.
